Name: WHYCOMMENT
Comment: Ok, I’ll get the ball rolling with some thoughts.. I am Jewish, born in the uk 1960, and have always had an emotional response to the Germans and their conduct in the second world war.  Whilst I believe that there were a lot of evil people in Germany during the war, such that there was a kind of “collective guilt”, I have also believed that you can not blame an entire nation, nor their children. With that in mind I watched this with great interest I watched and was actually captivated by it. I think I even enjoyed it! Germany was portrayed as a horrible place to live, especially for the “ordinary “people who must have been conflicted. Each brother seemed to know he’d lost his soul and his humanity and I guess it must have been difficult to resist the pressure to fit in. Humans readily accept the norm as being ok.And yet, most Germans did go along with things and you do wonder how much they succumbed to this –eg the family that took the flat of the Jewish family that was featured, readily took on the anti –Semitic stance of the regime with apparent ease. Perhaps there was a “German mentality” which is a phrase that I have heard used many times. So my conclusion is that this was a programme worth watching addressing difficult issues, that did not deny what a terrible place Germany must have been and that there was a cost to the country and its people. As a drama it felt well put together too. What it possibly could have addressed was the role that the German opposition took throughout Nazi rule took and if it had support, however passive, amongst the people.

So many times we have seen this all over the world - surely I don't need to start listing examples. In fact, I think it's dangerous to start throwing around the idea that these things occur because of a preponderance of inherently evil people, as if the people there at the time were qualitatively different to ourselves, because it lulls us into a false sense of security that it couldn't happen here, All you need, for example, is economic hardship, a relatively defenceless minority and cynical racist politicians with no qualms about exploiting the situation to gain power and inflict suffering on "the other". Suddenly the scenario doesn't seem so alien, does it........

Comment: The day before World War 2 ended, my father and his comrades in the Polish Forces were "our gallant Allies, the Poles". The day after they were "fascist thugs". In "When a Crocodile Eats the Sun", Peter Godwin writes movingly of the political betrayal suffered by his father and mine: "In the summer of 1946, the huge victory parade takes place down the Mall in London. Two million onlookers cheer wildly as King George V1 takes the salute from Allied soldiers of dozens of nations. In the skies overhead there is a massive fly-past. but though they are the fourth biggest Allied army, no Polish forces march that day. The new Warsaw regime, at Stalin's insistence, ignores its British invitation and stays away. And the Free Poles have not been invited. Anyway, they have nothing to celebrate. While everyone else is jubilant, many of them watch the victory parade in tears."The new Polish government said we were traitors, just a bunch of fascist thugs, and I realized I would never be able to go home to Poland". says my father. "And Cania, who had stayed behind with our unit in Germany, after I'd been sent back for officer training, realized the same thing. He couldn't bear it. He walked out of his tent one evening and shot himself". In the wake of the war, Poland was betrayed and handed over to Stalin, and it seems we have been vilified ever since. Apparently we feature as "baddies" in this TV programme (which I haven't seen). We have had a good lesson in the wisdom of staying neutral, I will say that. The countries that managed to do so did not suffer as Poland did, nor do they come in for this constant vilification.

Name: Tataumlives
Comment: As they said on the panel discussion there was something almost ahistorical about the characters and the idea odrinary Germans could fraternise openly with Jews in Germany by 1941, when most Jews had already been forced to emigrate or been round up into camps or transported eastward to the new ghettoes in Poland. The few who hadn't immigrated or yet been deported would have had a miserable experience left behind of being permanently abused and spat at and it's simply not plausible that they could have partaken of a scene of carefree fun at the opening of the film. Besides that I believe it was a serious offence for Jews to go anywhere without wearing a yellow star. The makers simply went too far to make the characters likeable to a modern young audience and to suggest that the corruption began with the war and not before is also taking the license to dangerous excess. Most Germans were already heavily indoctrinated and identified fervently with the Nazi system, its goals and its virulent hatred and persecution of the Jews. I was outraged by the writer who said they have 'no responsiblity' to portray history accurately. Writers should be given the right to take liberties with history for dramatic license, but when you're dealing with a topic like the Nazis and the Holocaust you have to tread carefully or you risk stepping over into revisionism, intentional or not, and I think this went close. In the film Starship Troopers we're given a fascinating albeit tongue-in-cheek portrayal of a Nazi-like society where everyone - even the audience - is invited to identify with a fascist system and the characters, who just accept their behaviour and the way society is ordered as normal. That portrayal of a fascist psychology was in many ways a more accurate, seductive and subversive depcition of life in a Nazi society was like than the admittedly enjoyable but unreal fantasy of Generation War. Despite its powerful dramatic impact I don't think history will be kind to this series.

Name: Enheduanna
Comment: The yellow star was compulsory for Jews after 19 September 1941, so it was possible that they did not have to wear it before (at the start of the series I think it is the spring of 1941). As for the friendship between them, the point of drama is to show what could happen, not what did happen. As Pirandello once remarked, reality will always beat the most fervent imagination. I think by criticising the friendship between the five young people, including one Jew, people are not criticising its improbability, but its function in humanising them. To an extent, this is a device, to make their eventual downfall and loss of innocence even more dramatic. And I think this is the point: people do not want to accept that these young Germans were innocent to start with, or in any way victims of the regime. But to an extent they were; they had grown up within Nazism and had known nothing else. The fact that they had preserved a certain amount of humanity and idealism, seems too much for most viewers who either want to cling on to the fiction that all Germans were guilty monsters, or want to stress their inhumanity to better distance themselves from them.

Comment: I don't think this series was meant to be a historically correct depiction of events and characters. There have been endless documentaries on hitler this and hitler that on German TV in the past. Maybe these should be shown on the BBC and we could discuss these in detail. No, I think the intention was to just show a present day German audience in a somewhat convoluted and sepia tinged way something of what "our mothers and fathers" did or didn't do. And to an extent it did just that.  I watched this on German TV with my father who was 14 at the end of the war. He lived in a small rural town. He only spoke about his youth when asked but watching this series opened quite a flood of memories for him and I am grateful I was there to listen. He feels tremendous guilt and regret. And no, he was not involved in the hitler youth, had to help on the farm. He has memories of various things, incl. people raiding the ware house of Jewish owned meat canning factory and seeing two men hanged. He was not involved in any of this and neither were his family but of course they did nothing to stop it. His only "war action" was being put into uniform with a gun in April 45 to defend the town - together with other school kids. When he was confronted by a member of the approaching US army and was able to tell them his name and age in his school English, they send him home. He said that this past will never leave us and he said that he has carried this shame with him all is life, this shame and this enormous feeling of guilt that he as a boy trusted and looked up to people - his teachers in school, his parents, his older brothers and cousins - who really must have known what was going on and who did nothing. He trusted them and accepted their judgement. He was healthy and young, he could read and ask. How could he have been so ignorant, so stupid and so inactive. There was little or no talk about the war during my childhood. I used to be outraged by this silence and used every opportunity to confront and to argue - still do. My father was not someone who would give out rules, but he was adamant about one thing, never join a crowd, stay away from the masses. Question authority, he always preached and we would yawn. I wonder how many other families in Germany had similar discussions after watching.

The regime certainly wasn't supported by everyone and Hitler probably couldn't believe his luck when he came to power, when nearly all subsequent historical commentary suggest that his political influence was on the wane when he was invited to form a government. However, he ruthlessly removed all opposition (read communists and social democrats, as well as any others who could be classified as 'endangering national security') within a few months of taking power. Ideological opponents had already been identified and were incarcerated, surveilled or curtailed in their activities. Close to where I live (in Germany) there is a concentration camp (KZ) where 600 political prisoners where held from 1933-35, including Kurt Schumacher a prominent SPD (Social Democrat) post-war leader - he was later transferred to Dachau. These camps were 2 of hundreds that sprung up to control Germans within months of Hitler taking power. This policy coupled with special (kangaroo) courts (Sondergerichte) flamed fear, suspicions and effectively curtailed much anti-nazi activity. Over 3.5 million Germans spent time in KZs, over 70,000 were executed for one form of resistance or other.There are often comments about how the German people went along with the nazis, but it is very difficult to resist when your life or your family's is threatened by your actions. Meanwhile for a sizeable number of the population, Hitler provided jobs and put bread on the table of the poorest families. It is difficult for us to know, with our relative affluence today, that not so long ago bread and a job were enough to secure someone's trust and support. Why would they question if most things (even the start of Hitler's war from 1939-40) appeared to support the Nazis' assertions of German supremacy -I don't recall uprisings or resistance by loyal Brits about the wrongs of colonialism while the going was good. As for the more intelligent, I suspect they knew to keep their heads down. Are the Iraqi people any less for not having resisted Saddam or Camodians Pol Pot? No. They too faced a situation where their resistance would only mean their death. Generation War is a fiction and there are some inconsistencies, but as a representation of the descent of men to madness and murder it works. I fail to see how anyone is trying to get off the hook here. The scene of the SS officer shooting the jewish girl is damning of the type of appalling violence that Germans were involved in. Or the wider story of Viktor Goldstein (the Jewish friend) facing anti-semitism from others than Nazis is representative of some european attitudes then and sadly still know. Still stronger is the descent of Friedhelm from educated man of letters to compromised and slavish obedience -primarily as a way of surviving. The representation of Wilhelm as an army soldier rather than a nazi is also reasonable as the army saw itself as an honourable and disciplined unit at least to start with in the war. I fail to see what is wrong with describing any or all of these people as victims. We are all victims of our choices as well as the behaviour of others. All sullied by our experiences. In Germany, this series was important as it prompted grandchildren and children to ask their parents, what did you do in the war? Perhaps a last chance to question a generation again. It seems very easy for us to stand at a distance and make judgements, without much idea of what it was like. However, what is clear, not only from this three part series but from our knowledge of conflict, is that once people feel threatened or see their neighbours bombed or killed, the sense and urgency of survival kicks in. In this state, people unite and fight, not for any great reasons or support for an ideology, just to survive.FYI, my family is English, Irish, Polish and Jewish. I don't hold much to such ethnic descriptions (put it this way, it doesn't define me). I only offer that information so that I'm not categorised as an apologist for German culpability, which I am most definitely not.

Name: SocalAlex
Comment: To be a Nazi you had to hate Jews. You couldn't possibly revere Hitler - be willing to die for the Fuhrer - on the one hand, whilst on the other hand thinking to yourself 'he's going a bit ape about the poor old Jews. They're surely not that bad'.   So incredibly simplistic I don't even know where to start. First of all, what do you even mean by "being a Nazi"? You have to distinguish between those who were genuine ideological Nazis (the party elite and the early adapters but yes, also many ordinary citizens), those who were "opportunistic" Nazis (it was a good career move) and those who were "paper" Nazis, who had little choice in the matter.  Only the first group actually "revered" Hitler; the other couple included people with a very broad cross-section of opinions and, indeed, people with no opinion much whatsoever. (E.g., to cite one extreme, Oskar Schindler was a very successful "opportunisic" Nazi to the end!) Secondly, it's patently untrue that every (or even most soldiers) were "willing to die for the Führer". Or even supported the goals of the Nazis. (You have to distinguish between the SS and the Wehrmacht.) Again, every man had his own story, but the truth on the ground was far more complicated than you describe. Many saw it as being willing to die for their country, as opposed to its regime, and many others simply saw it in terms of taking their oath of loyalty to their "brother soldiers" seriously. Indeed, the latter is the line taken by e.g. a number of active members of the White Rose resistance group, who were serving soldiers all the while they were also actively working to spark a popular revolt against Hitler! (I suggest you read or watch one of the numerous interviews with Fritz Hartnagel, the fiance of Sophie Scholl and later husband of one of her sisters, who survived Stalingrad, was judged a "Mitläufer"* by the de-nazification courts and who spent the rest of his life campaiging against war and fascism. He explained his thinking on this subject at the time very well - but I suspect the messy reality may exceed your black and white world view.)  The other point you seem to entirely miss is that your average German soldier - in common with your average soldier at every time and place in history - was far more interested in staying alive than in dying for anything! Given that the draft was universal, being a conscientious objector was not an option and the penalty for desertion/refusing your call-up was death if you were caught, "being willing to die" was your only real option one way or the other! Doing it "for Hitler" gave you a better chance at survival than "against Hitler". Frankly, I hope that had I been alive then, I would have had the courage of my convictions the way Sophie Scholl did of hers - but I'm honest enough to say, I'm not at all sure I would have. Would you have definitely refused military service/deserted and happily gone to the your execution instead? If you are willing to unequivocally say yes, then, with all due respect, I think you are lying, or you haven't actually thought about it deeply at all! *There is no real English equivalent to the German term Mitläufer , which I find a shame, as they exist at all times and in all places as well. Literally "someone who goes along with something", referring to people take part in a movement, ideology and/or action in a minor role, and without genuinely believing in it - in contrast to genuine sympathisers or "fellow travellers"... A large number if not the majority were Mitläufer, as opposed to Hitler-worshippers, and I think you greatly underestimate the degree of "indifference" that was indeed present...

Name: SocalAlex
Comment: I'm half Austrian. Perhaps, in your opinion, that makes me "biased"? My late Austrian grandma being an example. Born in 1912, into incredibly poor circumstances, she had no choice but to leave school to work in a shop at age 14. She was intelligent and intellectually curious, but her passions were art and music and literature, and till her dying day, two years ago, she remained a-political and completely disinterested in history and current affairs to a degree I (a political scientist "by trade" and self-described "news whore" and activist for as long as I can remember) found nearly impossible to even conceive!  She was also ambitious, teaching herself stenography and to speak more nicely in her free time and working her way up to a secretarial job in the local government and a lower middle-class lifestyle. One she -painfully class-conscious and appearance-conscious to her dying day as well - already then worried was "too good for" her. And so, knowing nothing of politics and current events and caring even less, her middle-class, well-educated superiors and colleagues told her the Nazis were a "good thing" she assumed they, being so much more clever and worldly were probably right, without bothering to look into it much in detail. (Did she vote for the Anschluss ? To be honest, I never - dared? - ask her; she probably either did or didn't vote at all, and if she did, it wasn't for ideological reasons, but because she was pretty much indifferent (she'd been born into a country which no longer existed, she'd already experienced three vastly different forms of government - the Austro-Hungarian empire, the first Austrian republic, and the short-lived home-grown fascist state - and the intervening chaos of the transitions, without being consciously personally affected by any of it) yet her "betters" (in her and society's opinion/in actual fact quite the opposite) told her to do so, and, in her words, "they must be right". And then, because she worked for her local government, which overnight went from being "Austrian" to "German", she had to join the Nazi party on paper to keep her job. At the beginning, she also saw the "benefits" of the Nazis - after all, they "gave" her her first paid vacation in over a decade and a half of full-time work -, and her naivite and genuine a-political indifference and the natural human tendency towards denial and repression kept her insulated from their full horror until it was too late.  Was she "anti-semitic"? Certainly no more and indeed far less so than many other people of similar backgrounds in the U.K. and the U.S. at the time. Was she "evil"? Certainly not! Her "crimes" were of omission rather than commission. The man who later became my grandfather also worked for the local government, but in a far more senior function. He refused to join the Nazi Party, and was promptly fired Already too old to be drafted he was unemployed for the duration of the war.  My grandmother's brother was a life-long Socialist. But he was equally poor and poorly-educated, and unlike her, was not ambitious. He was not "leader" material, he was no hero - which makes him no different from the vast majority of us. He remained a political activist, he continued to speak out openly against the Nazis as long as it was still "safe enough" to do so, and once it no longer was, he did so privately. And when he was drafted, he joined up and fought because - as "wrong" as you may find it - he wanted to live. As it happened, he didn't, dying a couple of weeks before the end of war; it took my grandmother/great-grandmother a few years to even find out that much and where. And it was only via Google and the paltry Red Cross documents they received that I could make an educated guess at the "how" a couple years ago - from injuries sustained by an America/British bombing raid, 3 days after the fact... So, was my grandmother "a Nazi"? Not according to the Americans who occupied her city - they didn't even judge her a candidate for minimal "denazification", but seemlessly continued to employ her!  Was her brother? Did he deserve to die? Are the children/grandchildren of those who killed him justified in gloating about it? Was my grandfather "evil/cowardly" for merely sacrificing his livelihood rather than his life? It's easy to self-righteously denounce all Germans as "evil" from your comfortable 2014 armchair. Honestly putting yourselves in their shoes isn't.  And it hasn't escaped my notice that the very people who tend to bang on loudest about the Nazis are the very ones most eager to defend the flagrant disregard for the rule of law and the illegal wars our own current Western governments are engaged in!

Comment: I thought Generation War was mostly excellent - a flawlessly acted, gripping, emotionally involving drama about a side of the war that felt new to me as a Brit (of German extraction - my grandparents left Berlin for London in the 1930s, partly for economic reasons but partly due to my grandfather's Jewish ancestry). Watching it was rather like reading All Quiet on the Western Front for the first time - a story you know very well but from a different viewpoint. The final episode didn't quite match up to the first two, with coincidences that felt contrived for dramatic necessity and therefore a bit clunky (Lilja, Victor/Friedhelm's meeting, the final three meeting back in the bar where it all began), but it was absorbing and moving. I do agree with a lot of the criticisms - for example, barely anyone appeared to be an enthusiastic Nazi, except for the members of the Gestapo or SS. I thought it let ordinary Germans off too easily - but then again, it quickly moved the action away from Berlin to the Eastern Front and barely came back until the end. Even so, the fact that the group of close friends who had grown up under the Third Reich included a Jewish man was raised in the discussion programme as unlikely, and did feel like a dramatic contrivance at best to include the Jewish experience in its "five friends" conceit (but even then Generation War avoided showing the concentration camps). The "war is hell" message was very clear, but perhaps more emphasis could have been put on what was particularly terrible about this war and Germany's part in it, especially the visceral racial hatred that was only really hinted at by the woman who moved into Victor's parents' house and the SS officer who shot a little girl. I didn't think that the programme was trying to suggest that all partisans were anti-semitic, but if I were Polish I might well have felt indignant about that, and that point was well covered in the discussion programme afterwards. The cast was generally excellent, but I would pick out Friedhelm in particular, whose transformation from sensitive naif to nihilistic killer was incredibly well acted. Friedhelm was so damaged and had done such terrible things that there was no way back for him, and his "suicide by Russians" made emotional sense. By contrast, Greta had a rather underwritten final episode - all the big drama for her happened in episode 2, and the prison scenes didn't seem to add much. Was it perfect? No. Was it historically accurate? Probably not. But it was a gripping and absorbing TV drama, and the conversations it has sparked are interesting and important ones. If I have one complaint, it was that it shied away from the the most difficult issues - we never saw the concentration camps, we weren't really shown what it was that turned Nazi Germany into a byword for evil. Maybe that wasn't the story it set out to tell - but it could have done more there.

The point the reviewer makes is that these were not typical young people of the time. Even ZDF producer Benedict did not make the claim that the five young friends were typical, but only that such friendships (Germans and Jews in 1941) were just possible. The problem with this portrayal of everyone's 'mothers or fathers' was that exceptional people were shown to be representative of the young Germans of the day when they clearly were not.. By contrast, we had the Polish partisans as types, not exceptions, and these types were almost exclusively anti-Semitic. ZDF has therefore taken the best Germans and presented them as typical and taken the worst Poles and presented those as typical. Fair? I don't think so. The scene with the freight cars and the AK (not sure if a spoiler alert is really necessry at this point, since this has been available on clips for many months) raises the following question: Viktor says: "A co z nimi?" (What about them?) "Are they supposed to die like that?" The partisan replies: "Most of them are Jews. And Jews are as bad as communists or Russkies. Better dead than alive." So - the partisan is acknowledging that there may be some non-Jews on board. But since he hates Jews so much, he is willing to sacrifice even those individuals.  No wonder the Polish ambassador called this scene "absurd".Others have been far less charitable.

Comment: I am sure you could five find young people in Britain gather them together and they wouldn't be able to tell you in detail what's been going on in the world around them...

Name: brambalus
Comment: Very much enjoyed the series which, despite its historical flaws, proved to be a good deal more accurate than most American war series and movies and certainly way better than the BBC's lacklustre 'Crimson Field' in terms of direction, dramatic tension and cinematography. The hospital scenes were gripping, bloody and totally realistic as was the depiction of the hell that was the Eastern Front. In many ways it echoed Joseph Vilsmaier's movie 'Stalingrad'. Sadly the series was badly promoted and badly scheduled and as a result probably only attracted a small audience.

Name: HermanTheHun
Comment: Watching this discussion I can't help the feeling that all of those kind contributors of this discussion - me included - , all of us children of democracy and its sure feeling of that inalienable right of free expression (except of course to your boss - you don't want to get fired), I can't help the feeling that we all don't know how it is to live in a dictatorship ,who clearly shows its ruthlessness in snatching people from the streets, in spreading fear by those rumors about concentration camps (the first prisoners of these camps were German communists and social democrats, not Jews), in forcing you to a military training in which you had hardly any rights whatsoever. I have asked myself the question many how I would have reacted in these times, and I simply don't know. And I have to smile whenever somebody comes up with a clear and noble answer. Maybe the Germans are just fed up with the average English, American, Dutch, French, whatever moral Herrenmensch, who wants to rub his inherited moral superiority in this miserable Jerry to show him his place. Believe me, I know what I am talking about. So they made a movie in which one possible aspect of the life in this time is shown, while knowing that it can't be complete.As for those who want to have a full, accurate and complete picture of this time, why don't you watch these superb British movies with noble and gallant British officers, politicians and people and these nasty, cruel and cold German Nazi officers. Now this is historic truth!

Name: Fionnbarra61
Comment: Herman, none of us know how we would behave if we were thrown into the Hieronymus Bosch painting that was totalitarian Germany for it's 12 years. Thankfully you and I don't have to live there. Those poor souls can be judged harshly but we have no idea how peer pressure, coercian, bloody mindedness really motivated them. It's easy to be an armchair Nuremburg Judge.

Name: daisydill
Comment: Herman, my father was a Polish para, who fought (on the Allied Side). And I loved him very much. But, as I have said above, isn't the truth about WW2 that both sides did terrible ungodly things? I don't see that either side has the high moral ground here. There was Stalin on one side, and Hitler on the other. Both killed millions. Hadn't Stalin killed millions of Ukrainians before WW2 even began, so he kind of had a head start. I haven't seen the programme, but am glad that Germans can tell their story. I don't usually watch or read anything about WW2, but I did watch Das Boot many years ago, and thought it very powerful. The claustrophobic nature of that submarine - and those brave and terrified young men... It was heartbreaking really.  All I am objecting to is Poland being made responsible for Axis crimes. We have of course to take our share of responsibility for Allied war crimes.  And, no, those of us who have not been put in the situation Germans were at that time should not be judging. Though I would like to say something about the German Christian congregation, the Earnest Bible Students, or Jehovah's Witnesses, who refused even to "Heil" Hitler, let alone join his Nazi party or his army, and they suffered terribly for it. They stood firm throughout the Hitler years, and even though many were killed, they survived as a congregation.

Name: Bangorstu
Comment: I don't see that either side has the high moral ground here.   I think the Western allies at least have some claim to moral superiority - no Katyn massacres there. And then they rather nicely paid for Western Germany to be put back on its feet.    We have of course to take our share of responsibility for Allied war crimes.   Like what? The Poles in the Red Army probably had their part in the destruction and rape of much of Germany but to be frank it's difficult to put yourself in their shoes. Poland lost 20% of its population in five years. That's a hell of a lot of vengeance. We all smile at the Pole sin 'Battle of Britain' disobeying orders and tearing into the Germans, but it's worth remembering what they had already been through and why they played by different rules to the British. Remember the Dutch surrendered because the Germans bluntly reminded them that Dutch cities were made of wood and they couldn't stop the Germans firestorming each and every one of them.

Name: shhush
Comment: The Poles in the Red Army probably had their part in the destruction and rape of much of Germany but to be frank it's difficult to put yourself in their shoes.   An estimated 2 million German women were raped at the end of the war. You appear to be attempting to justify this.

Name: daisydill
Comment: I do understand the terrible position Poland was put in. My father was a Polish para. And his family, what remained of it, were cut off behind the iron curtain after the war. His mother survived but he was never able to see her again. But, yes, I was thinking about the mass rape carried out on the conquered civilian population in the wake of the war. And the fire-bombing of Dresden.  Those are surely war crimes too?

Name: Bangorstu
Comment: An estimated 2 million German women were raped at the end of the war. You appear to be attempting to justify this.   It was obviously a war crime and I don't justify it. But given what the soldiers of the Red Army had seen, I can understand it. Certainly it's much more understandable than what the Wehrmacht did to Poland and the Soviet Union - the Red Army at least had the excuse of revenge.

Name: Bangorstu
Comment: The mass bombing of German cities was certainly justified - the factories were producing weapons and it makes a horrific sense to target the workers as well. And, note, the Germans were the first to use that tactic so the line had been crossed.  Dresden is a controversial case. Certainly an argument can be made for bombing it - it was a communications hub and had over a hundred factories. Our purpose was, after all, to help the red Army and save Soviet lives rather than German ones. Whether the bombing was proportionate is another thing. Technically incidentally not a war crime as aerial bombing wasn't covered by the Hague Conventions of the time.

Name: daisydill
Comment: OK, Bangorstu, clearly the fire bombing of Dresden was not a war crime in the legal sense - though a horrible thing in itself - but the mass rape surely was. I don't know if any Polish soldiers were involved in it! I very much hope not - but they could have been. I thought it was carried out, as a matter of policy, by the Red Army I just wanted to make the point that I couldn't object to Poland taking its share of the blame for Allied crimes, but it is not responsible for the crimes of the Axis Powers. War is an awful business. Which is why they should never get started in the first place.

Name: Bangorstu
Comment: Mass rape is definitely a war crime. There does seem to be something in the male psyche which, after being exposed to extreme combat, makes them prone to that kind of behaviour as a kind of catharsis. Witness the British sack of Badajoz in Spain in 1812 for an example. Or indeed the behaviour of the Red Army or for that matter soldiers just about everywhere. That's not to excuse it - firm discipline and control by officers is required, but to explain why it seems to happen. IIRC the Red Army in taking Berlin were told that the women were there for the taking (in anticipation of extreme casualties) which elevates the crime somewhat. As you say, it's different if made policy. Were Poles involved? I expect so - there were plenty fighting alongside the Russians and I doubt they behaved any better.

Name: brambalus
Comment: Dresden was horrific. I first read about the bombing in Kurt Vonnegut's 'Slaugherhouse 5', but since then am shocked at the devastation that was wreaked on a civilian population. Bomber Harris was a war criminal in the opinion of many and even disowned by Churchill after the war.

Name: daisydill
Comment: Which, Bangorstu, is why we should "lay down" our swords and "study war no more". Both sides did terrible things.  And any of us, if caught up in it, might have been induced to do terrible things. Especially if we felt entitled to take revenge.  At any rate, had I seen this programme - which I have not and don't intend to - it seems it would have reinforced the wisdom of the advice in the Inspired Scriptures. Which, to end on a positive note, is one thing I can say in its favour.

Name: SolarTime2012
Comment: The ONLY reason that the mass bombing of cities was not a legal war crime while obviously being a war crime is because in the 1930's there was a conference of lawyers to make bombing of civilians and cities a war crime. Name: RougeTrooper

Name: BlughGrant
Comment: I thought it was a moving and very well made portrayal of the German part of that generation lost to madness and war. I don't think it showed the characters as being in any way unaware or naive of what was going on around them - they were all well aware right at the start of what danger there was for Viktor - or of all being conveniently anti-Nazi, indeed some of them were shown to be very much subscribed to believing in the war and victory. And yet while at the same time sure, they had a Jewish friend, and sure they were naive in their attitudes towards the war and what it would involve, to say that those paradoxes are unrealistic is wrong. Those paradoxes are what make them ultimately human characters, in denial of the truths they want to conveniently ignore so they can try and carry on living their normal lives. Any drama that attempts to take on such a subject matter and allow it's characters to be actual human beings that we can't simply see as villains is making a big target of itself, but it's important that these things are tried because the reality isn't so conveniently black and white as "all germans were bad guys".

Name: aandrew1958

Name: martin77
Comment: " I also thought it was one of the most interesting and moving things I have seen on television in a while: superbly acted, gripping and challenging. " I couldn't agree more. Name: sanspeur
Comment: I thought it was too lightweight.Relating everything to the experiences of a few young people has something to commend it, the drama was easy to follow.But the subject matter is still very raw.As I said on another blog, I think that the systematic, wide ranging , brutal effects of the Nazi system were underplayed.A trainload of Jews in the middle of a landscape, in a random scene, can't be a substitute for the many death camps and forced labour sites, where millions died, transported from all over Europe.There were scenes of brutality in the combat zones.I watched the discussion programme which was aired after the last episode of this drama.I agreed that some of it was far fetched.The existence of a public relationship between a woman and her Jewish lover in 1941 I thought unrealistic.

Name: cycokan
Comment: The point of this drama, not documentary, series is clearly addressed in it's original title: "Our mothers, our fathers".  The intention was not a documentary like, 100% accurate picture of the war or the holocaust or any other aspect of WW2 in Germany, the intention was to trigger a discussion with our fathers, mothers, in reality more our grandparents, at the last chance before the last remaining eye witnesses and participants die.The question was also not only, what did the majority, different minorities, or even the artificial constructed average German do during the war, it questioned also, how the survivors mentality was damaged through the gruesome things they did by themselves, where done to them, or had witnessed during the dictatorship and the war. The survivors were our parents and grandparents, who had to live on after the war and mostly tried to be our good and beloved parents, tried to rebuild Germany, tried to re-socialise, tried to come clear with their guilt, often lied about their personal involvement, mostly simply kept quiet and avoided to speak about their personal experiences. All aspects of the war, all German mistakes and cruelties have been subject to hundreds and thousands of books, TV documentations and TV dramas, which still are in the media on daily basis. Our children get educated about them and the Nazi era remains the most wide spread issue of the curricula. There is nothing unknown in Germany and nothing is hidden or forgotten. On this background, it was much more intensive to pick a group of bohemian, liberal and educated, metropolitan youths, than a group of Nazi ideologists. In this discussion the question was asked, whether it was plausible, to have a Jewish friend in such a group in spring 1941. Surely not the standard, but possible. At least not more impossible, as a mixed group of friends mixed from bohemian, educated liberals and enthusiastic Nazis would have been.  One has to remember, that never, even at the highest point of "Gleichschaltung", when party membership was more or less mandatory for career clerks and officials in any part of government and society, not more than 8 million Germans joined the NSDAP.There remained millions of people who were communists, socialists, liberals, christdemocratic conservatives at heart, who couldn't speak out openly any more and even more millions of political uninterested people. On the other hand, summer 1941 was the absolute peak of the Nazi regime, the people had jobs, Poland and France were invaded in few weeks, the systematic extinction of the Jews had not yet begun and already practised war crimes were not commonly public. Even emphatic objectors of the Nazis started to think, that maybe not all they did was that wrong, in the light of their first successes. The point of the series was not to show, that maybe your father, your mother, was a Nazi party leader or a camp commander in Auschwitz. Most of them are known and were prosecuted, so their children normally know about their parents activities during the war.  The point was, that even ordinary people, yet even cultivated and educated middle class bohemians, our beloved mothers and fathers, actively took part in, but also received, unimaginable gruesome and inhuman crimes during the war.  How was this possible and why did they not want to speak about it? To protect themselves, to just forget, shame, because they thought it's to gruesome to involve their children? Not all actions of the series were representative or common, but all of them did happen somewhere, sometimes.To pick just those aspects the authors did, was fully legitimate to construct a story for a series that intended to trigger German self reflection. Others may, or may be not allowed to generalize all WW2 Germans as monsters, we instead have to come clear with the monster in ourselves.

Name: ReinerNiemand
Comment: Many miss the powerful feeling of US against THEM the Nazi Propaganda created quite successfully, US being the germans of the time and THEM all others, first the Jews, then the polish, russian, french, british, american, aso.The same common purpose bound together the german people into the Nazi Volksgemeinschaft (Peoples unity) against the known enemies, and swore them to a common goal (Deutschlands Wiederauferstehung/Resurrection of Germany). Not to forget the first years of the war being supremely successful on the military front. The germans really thought, they could win the war. And for the jews; anyone with a brain could see they were unjustly mistreated, but the Propaganda managed to draw a veil about the extend, and the final means. Nevertheless anyone with a brain, and an ear to the rumor mill did know what happened to them. But most did not want to know, and later denied any involvement, Speer beeing a primary example.The Wannsee conference (Endlösung der Judenfrage/Final solution of the jewish question) was held without Hitlers explicit consent and knowledge, to isolate his political persona from any possible fallout, because no leader should be involved in such inhuman policies.The DDR Propaganda later did the same against the western democracies, also very successfully and pervasive. Pervasive to the point of older eastern germans intensive feelings of having lost the common purpose (Schaffung des sozialistischen Menschen/Creation of the socialist human).

Name: Rob1949
Comment: I found this programme quite gripping and very well acted. German in origin, I would be surprised if it didn't portray the German people with some sympathy. Let's face it, in all USA war productions they won the war. As far as this production is concerned, I thought it was very well put together and each viewing made me impatient for the next in the series. I can remember finding a book in my parents wardrobe (kids!) called 'Lest we forget" which at the age of ten, traumatised me. I could not believe that people could be so cruel and basically, evil. As much as I have tried to forget and forgive, it never really leaves me which I know is wrong but I can't help it.

Name: Rob1949
Comment: As much as I feel as I stated on my previous posting I can't and we can't hold current generations responsible for the evils of their fathers of grandfathers (grandmothers too?) I am also aware that under the right conditions we are all capable of inflicting immense cruelty on our fellow man and that is a sad check with reality. '...cast the first stone' and all that. But crumbs, what a moving experience, at the end I almost cried. Can we have some more please, wonderful to get a German perspective. Thank you.

Name: brithistory84
Comment: Judging this film as a drama, which is the ONLY way it should be interpreted, I would say it is powerful.However the danger comes when one views it as an expression of historical discussion. Apart from highly unlikely circumstances/ occurrences in this film it leaves me with a taste that it tends towards sympathy for the leading German characters and population whilst emphasizing atrocities committed by other nationals portrayed in the film i.e Polish resistance fighters, Russian soldiers. I can understand why this film would offend some people and my concern is people not solely taking this production as a fictional work So much progress has been made by many nations in coming to terms with conduct in the Second World War and to look back with such "creative licence" is perhaps a large step back or worse, dangerous.

Name: SolarTime2012
Comment: Considering what utter tosh the BBC WWI effort THE ARK is in its good war run by nice posh people fairy tale...the post-mortem remark can get put where the sun don't shine. Yes GEN WAR is flawed but it is also very human and very well done.One should note the characters do come from Berlin. Berlin did not votefor Hitler and had no ghetto.

Name: WulfrunianInGermany
Comment: I haven't the time to read through all the previous comments, many of which will no doubt already have said what I will write here. So here's my take. The main criticisms (both inside and outside Germany) were 1) the continued friendship in mid-1941 of young Germans with their Jewish childhood friend. I don't think this was the norm, but not improbable either: Goebbels for example complained in his diary that after years of state-run hate propanda, most Germans now had a healthy dislike of the evil, often foreign, often leftwing caricature Jews depicted by that propaganda, but many also made exceptions for their own Jews; the secular, patriotic and non-hooked-nosed German Jews they'd known all their livesm who'd fought in the Great War and who obviously didn't resemble the caricature Jews in any way. This feat of cognitive dissonance annoyed Goebbels a lot, but it's well attested. Most Jews were still living in their old homes at this time, and many of them clearly never believed it would get so bad as it did. Deportations didn't come until much later, and even then very few people knew what was happening. We can't use our hindsight to makelazy judgements here. 2) Anti-Semitism of Poles. This caused a furore in Poland, but unfortunately it was true of a significant proportion of this deeply Catholic people. The German makers of the film perhaps missed an opportunity to present within the resistance group the full spectrum of Polish attitudes towards the Jews, which ranged from sympathy to hatred. 3) The plot device of the characters repeatedly meeting by chance on the vast Russian front is just that: coincidences worthy of a Dickens novel. But this is drama, not a documentary, and otherwise the drama of five characters simply wouldn't work. 4) Some critics say the Germans (including the four main protagonists) are shown too sympathetically. In fact they are all guilty of crimes of commission and omission, of betrayal. The other German characters shown, whether in Berlin or at the front, both male and female, are also shown in a fairly negative light. How can that be sympathetic treatment?  All in all, this was a very nuanced and thought-provoking series, long overdue.

Name: BlutoBlutarsky
Comment: Busy lifestyle, eh? Watch out for that blood pressure, brother. If you had taken the time to read some of the other comments, you might have noticed that one flaw with this series which was pointed out was that five unlikely (and likeable) friends had been presented as the norm in 1940s Germany ('Our mothers,our fathers'), at the same time as thoroughly unpleasant and viciously anti-Semitic thugs were presented as the Polish norm. Where's the Teutonic sense of Gerechtigkeit? As for Poland being a 'deeply Catholic country' - it wasn't always like that, you know. It only became much more Catholic after 1945 for obvious reasons...

Name: Gammelpreusse
Comment: Hate to bring it to you, but these kinda people were as part of the norm as rapists, political activists, communists, nazis, chimney sweepers, sadists, humanists, artists etc. etc., each with their own stories, attitudes and "truths". Nazi stereotypes we had for 70 years straight.

Name: BlutoBlutarsky
Comment: I think you missed my point. I don't disagree with you about Nazi stereotypes, but it's ZDF which is doing the stereotyping now. They took the best Germans and presented them as typical, and took the worst Poles and presented those as typical. Not exactly fair, is it?

Name: Gammelpreusse
Comment: And before all everybody took was the worst Nazis and presenting them as stereotypes. Was that fair? Besides, I hardly consider these folks as the "best" Germans, given what they did in this miniseries. That is what confuses me so much. They shoot children, drive civilians through minefields, execute village people as partisan revenge, report "jews", all the stuff you read and hear about. I seriously do not get the point here.  About the Poles, that indeed could have handled better, presenting a more diverse truth.

Name: BlutoBlutarsky
Comment: I agree with you that the friends do some terrible things (four of them, to be precise). That seems to me to be the point of the series - how war dehumanizes people, and I have no problem whatsoever with that and the film makes that credible. My point is that the friends were originally (in 1941 - after years of Nazi propaganda) still very nice people, pretty much like your average 21st century young German. That's the unbelievable bit. Especially if you consider what Wilhelm must have been doing in Poland in 1939, and yet he is still more or less an innocent in 1941 and great friends with Viktor.

Name: Gammelpreusse
Comment: You comment implies that "every" german in Poland was comitting war crimes and/or saw terrible things happen and became a bitter or serious person over it. And though terrible things "did" happen, that is not what happend, or was witnessed by every german there. Unluckily the show does say nothing if that guy was in Poland (or stationed on the French border, for example) and what he did there, so that is up for pure speculation.  Also, the most disgusting crimes were done by command units that came behind the fighting units. And even though the regular Wehrmacht was involved in warcrimes in Poland from day one, it did not involve every single unit. After Poland the bulk of the Army was pulled to the western front in preperation of the invasion of France. What a lot of people miss is that the bloodiest chapters of the war and the Holocaust began only with the invasion of the Soviet Union in 1941, the Holocaust after the Wannsee Conference in 1942. Before that, killings alrerady happend, but not to the degree and as widespread as in later years, so it's not as far fetched as you make it out to be that the people in 41 there were emotionally still rather intact.  Finally, contrary to popular belief, Germans back then were not a monolithic society all brainwashed in Nazi ideology. Nazi support was wiedespread, but for some very different reasons amongst different people. Pretty much everybody had that one decent jew who was alright, looked alright and behaved alright, unlike the propaganda caricatures presented all the time. Is it unlikely they had such a jewish friend? yes? Impossible or implausible even? nope.  These people were not stereotypical...but then, hardly anybody was. Some were worse, some were better. Look around in your own society today, you will see people with very different backgrounds and very different opinions, supporting parties, ideas, arguments for their very own reasons and interests. Some are more radical, some less, some do not hold an opinion at all towards certain topics. It was no different back then.  The show ran outside the usual stereotypes and you have to see in the context of all the shows and movies done during the last 70 years that did not allow derivation from a very singular and one dimensional description of the Hitler fanatic as the typical german. This Propaganda, that never stopped after the war, itself has become such a common knowledge that it is interesting how much a more varied showing produces such disbelief.  Btw, I am German. I had grandfathers. One was a hard core Nazi "Bonze" in Bavaria, the other was a Luftwaffe Officer from Northrhine Westphalia who served in France, Africa and Italy, commanding a FlaK battery. If you compare their stories and attitudes side by side, it was if both were living on different planets.

Name: BlutoBlutarsky
Comment: Thanks for your comments, GP. I don't mean to dismiss either your views or those of Wulfrunian (above) but as you can see, what particularly gets to me is the total caricature of the Polish resistance. As you might have guessed, I'm from a Polish background and I get fed up with Poles being stereotyped as moronic anti-Semites. That ZDF should have perpetuated this is particularly irksome, because what you say about their portrayal of ordinary Germans is mostly fair. No-one is saying that decent Germans didn't exist, but why make the Poles the nasty guys? It wasn't them who crossed the German border in September 1939.

Name: BlutoBlutarsky
Comment: And when you talk about the 'bloodiest chapters' not taking place until 1941, then I'd beg to differ. What about the bombing of Polish cities or the indiscriminate strafing of columns of civilians? It wasn't just the Gestapo and fanatical Nazis who were flying those planes.

Name: Gammelpreusse
Comment: Fair enough, understand your reasoning here. And yeah, to be honest, I too did not quite understand this twist, either. But as someone who is quite read up in regards to polish history, what the Germans did there, the Warsaw Ghetto and the uprising late in the war, that part of the series was not my focal point.  I "think" it was due to the fact she show wanted to present the view that collaboration and antisemtitism was very, very widespread in Europa at that time. There is a lot of legend building in many european countries about everybody being in a resistance movement and being moral angles, which is far, far from the truth. But neither were there all rabid jew haters, so in this regard, I understand the irritation that must have caused amongst many.

Name: Gammelpreusse
Comment: I beg to differ.  When I say "bloodiest" chapters, I was referring to what happend behind the frontlines, Commando units, concentration camps, mass shootings etc. Those far exceeded everything that was happening on the frontlines even taking bombings of cities and strafing civilians into account.  The examples you brought were done by every side in this war involved and is still done to this day by even the most self declared "civilized" nations around. That is why I am a pacifist. War removes that certain layer of accountability for personal actions, and some people will just let go. That is not a national trait, that is a human trait.

Name: BlutoBlutarsky
Comment: GP, you are a civilised human being and thanks for taking the trouble to answer, point by point. As you may have seen from my comments further down, I lived in Germany for some years and have nothing but good memories. (And it's always good to remind everyone that the Germans produced Goethe, Schiller, ETA Hoffman, Kleist, Brecht and others who I can't think of off the top of my head). Alles Gute, Freund...

Name: BlutoBlutarsky
Comment: But if you know your Polish history as you say you do, then you will probably agree that, compared to some other European countries, collaboration was pretty minimal.

Name: Gammelpreusse
Comment: No harm done, Bluto, we all are influenced by this period of time in one way or another, only thing to solve it is to actually talk about it. Thumbs up! In regards to the polish collaboration...I honestly don't know about that one. I mean, no state can stay occupied for any lengh of time without serious collaboration by at least parts of any given population, without it there simply is no way to maintain an occupation. But I never read anything in particular towards the polish situation here, I have to admit.

Name: BlutoBlutarsky
Comment: The phrase "Jaw, jaw is better than war, war" was used by Churchill himself, of course, ironically enough, since he was the UK war leader. For a Polish perspective I'd recommend Halik Kochanski's book about WWII.  Cheers. Must go and eat my bigos.
